H0.text: Which Dutch govenor, in 1664, tried to resist the British seizure of New York. Willem Kieft

H1.text: Which Dutch govenor, in 1664, tried to resist the British seizure of New York. Cornelis Jacobszoon May

H2.text: Which Dutch govenor, in 1664, tried to resist the British seizure of New York. Adriaen van der Donck

H3.text: Which Dutch govenor, in 1664, tried to resist the British seizure of New York. PETER STUYVESANT

A4.text: In 1664, England sent an expeditionary force to capture New Netherland. The colony's settlers refused to fight, forcing Stuyvesant to surrender and demonstrating the dilemma of domestic dissatisfaction, small size, and overwhelming external pressures with inadequate military support from the Company that was fixated on profits.

A5.text: On 6 September 1664, Stuyvesant sent Johannes de Decker, a lawyer for the West India Company, and five others to sign the Articles of Capitulation.

A6.text: Stuyvesant negotiated good terms from his 'too powerful enemies'.

A7.text: They met no resistance to the capture of New Amsterdam.

A8.text: England seized the colony from the Dutch in 1664, renaming it the Province of New York.

A9.text: Stuyvesant surrendered to the English in 1664.

A10.text: In 1664, unable to summon any significant resistance, Stuyvesant surrendered New Amsterdam to English troops, led by Colonel Richard Nicolls, without bloodshed.
